body_content.explanation: to take hold of something suddenly and roughly:
examples: He snatched the photos out of my hand before I had a chance to look at them.
Running the best race of his career, Fletcher snatched (= only just won) the gold medal from the Canadian champion.

body_content.explanation: to take something or someone away by force:
examples: The six-year-old girl was snatched from a playground and her body was found two days later.
She had her purse snatched (= stolen) while she was shopping.

body_content.explanation: to do or get something quickly because you only have a short amount of time:
examples: Maybe you'll be able to snatch a couple of hours' sleep before dinner.

body_content.explanation: to get or win something, especially suddenly, unexpectedly, or by a small amount:
examples: She quickly broke serve and snatched an early lead.
They snatched an equaliser in the closing seconds of the game.
They finally snatched a draw with an injury-time goal.

body_content.explanation: the action of trying to take something quickly and forcefully:
examples: I felt someone behind me make a snatch at my bag.
I tried to hear what they were saying, but I only managed to catch a few snatches of conversation.

body_content.explanation: a rude word for a vagina
